abstract_sentences.1: In recent years word-embedding models have gained great popularity due to their remarkable performance on several tasks, including word analogy questions and caption generation.
abstract_sentences.2: An unexpected “sideeffect” of such models is that their vectors often exhibit compositionality, i.e., adding two word-vectors results in a vector that is only a small angle away from the vector of a word representing the semantic composite of the original words, e.g., “man” + “royal” = “king”.
abstract_sentences.3: This work provides a theoretical justification for the presence of additive compositionality in word vectors learned using the Skip-Gram model.
abstract_sentences.4: In particular, it shows that additive compositionality holds in an even stricter sense (small distance rather than small angle) under certain assumptions on the process generating the corpus.
abstract_sentences.5: As a corollary, it explains the success of vector calculus in solving word analogies.
abstract_sentences.6: When these assumptions do not hold, this work describes the correct non-linear composition operator.
abstract_sentences.7: Finally, this work establishes a connection between the Skip-Gram model and the Sufficient Dimensionality Reduction (SDR) framework of Globerson and Tishby: the parameters of SDR models can be obtained from those of Skip-Gram models simply by adding information on symbol frequencies.
abstract_sentences.8: This shows that SkipGram embeddings are optimal in the sense of Globerson and Tishby and, further, implies that the heuristics commonly used to approximately fit Skip-Gram models can be used to fit SDR models.

This work provides a theoretical justification for the presence of additive compositionality in word vectors learned using the Skip-Gram model.
body_sentences.2: In particular, it shows that additive compositionality holds in an even stricter sense (small distance rather than small angle) under certain assumptions on the process generating the corpus.
body_sentences.3: As a corollary, it explains the success of vector calculus in solving word analogies.
body_sentences.4: When these assumptions do not hold, this work describes the correct non-linear composition operator.
body_sentences.5: Finally, this work establishes a connection between the Skip-Gram model and the Sufficient Dimensionality Reduction (SDR) framework of Globerson and Tishby: the parameters of SDR models can be obtained from those of Skip-Gram models simply by adding information on symbol frequencies.
body_sentences.6: This shows that SkipGram embeddings are optimal in the sense of Globerson and Tishby and, further, implies that the heuristics commonly used to approximately fit Skip-Gram models can be used to fit SDR models.
body_sentences.7: 1 Introduction  The strategy of representing words as vectors has a long history in computational linguistics and machine learning.
body_sentences.8: The general idea is to find a map from words to vectors such that wordsimilarity and vector-similarity are in correspondence.
body_sentences.9: Whilst vector-similarity can be readily quantified in terms of distances and angles, quantifying word-similarity is a more ambiguous task.
body_sentences.10: A key insight in that regard is to posit that the meaning of a word is captured by “the company it keeps” (Firth, 1957) and, therefore, that two words that keep company with similar words are likely to be similar themselves.
body_sentences.11: In the simplest case, one seeks vectors whose inner products approximate the co-occurrence frequencies.
body_sentences.12: In more sophisticated methods cooccurrences are reweighed to suppress the effect of more frequent words (Rohde et al., 2006) and/or to emphasize pairs of words whose co-occurrence frequency maximally deviates from the independence assumption (Church and Hanks, 1990).
body_sentences.13: An alternative to seeking word-embeddings that reflect co-occurrence statistics is to extract the vectorial representation of words from non-linear statistical language models, specifically neural networks.
body_sentences.14: (Bengio et al., 2003) already proposed (i) associating with each vocabulary word a feature vector, (ii) expressing the probability function of word sequences in terms of the feature vectors of the words in the sequence, and (iii) learning simultaneously the vectors and the parameters of the probability function.
body_sentences.15: This approach came into prominence recently through works of Mikolov et al.

body_sentences.17: An unexpected side effect of deriving wordembeddings via neural networks is that the wordvectors produced appear to enjoy (approximate) additive compositionality: adding two wordvectors often results in a vector whose nearest word-vector belongs to the word capturing the composition of the added words, e.g., “man” + “royal” = “king” (Mikolov et al., 2013c).
body_sentences.18:

v(king) - v(man) + v(woman).

body_sentences.172: 3 Skip-Gram learns a Sufficient Dimensionality Reduction Model  The Skip-Gram model assumes that the distribution of the neighbors of a word follows a specific exponential parametrization of a categorical distribution.
body_sentences.173: There is empirical evidence that this model generates features that are useful for NLP tasks, but there is no a priori guarantee that the training corpus was generated in this manner.
body_sentences.174: In this section, we provide theoretical support for the usefulness of the features learned even when the SkipGram model is misspecified.
body_sentences.175: To do so, we draw a connection between SkipGram and the Sufficient Dimensionality Reduction (SDR) factorization of Globerson and Tishby (Globerson and Tishby, 2003).
body_sentences.176:
The SDR model
learns optimal2 embeddings for discrete random variables X and Y without assuming any parametric form on the distributions of X and Y , and it is useful in a variety of applications, including information retrieval, document classification, and association analysis (Globerson and Tishby, 2003).
body_sentences.177: As it turns out, these embeddings, like Skip-Gram, are obtained by learning the parameters of an exponentially parameterized distribution.
body_sentences.178: In Theorem 3 below, we show that if a SkipGram model is fit to the cooccurence statistics of X and Y , then the output can be trivially modified (by adding readily-available information on word frequencies) to obtain the parameters of an SDR model.
body_sentences.179: This connection is significant for two reasons: first, the original algorithm of (Globerson and Tishby, 2003) for learning SDR embeddings is expensive, as it involves information projections.
body_sentences.180: Theorem 3 shows that if one can efficiently fit a Skip-Gram model, then one can efficiently fit an SDR model.
body_sentences.181: This implies that Skip-Gram specific approximation heuristics like negativesampling, hierarchical softmax, and Glove, which are believed to return high-quality approximations to Skip-Gram parameters (Mikolov et al., 2013b; Pennington et al., 2014), can be used to efficiently approximate SDR model parameters.
body_sentences.182: Second, (Globerson and Tishby, 2003) argues for the optimality of the SDR embedding in any domain where the training information on X and Y consists of their coocurrence statistics; this optimality and the Skip-Gram/SDR connection argues for the use of Skip-Gram approximations in such domains, and supports the positive experimental results that have been observed in applications in network science (Grover and Leskovec, 2016), proteinomics (Asgari and Mofrad, 2015), and other fields.
body_sentences.183: As stated above, the SDR factorization solves the problem of finding information-theoretically optimal features, given co-occurrence statistics for a pair of discrete random variables X and Y .
